You can score whole (e.g., 5.0, 6.0, 7.0) or half (e.g., 5.5, 6.5, 7.5) bands in each part of the test. If you get greater or equal to .25 after decimal point for example 7.25 score will be marge to 7.5. But if you score greater or equal to .75 after decimal point your score will be marge to a whole number for example 6.75 will be 7. Tips To Follow : 
 

1. In listening test there are 4 sections and within this 4 sections section 1 is the easiest one, section 2 is a bit harder than section.But the remaining 2 sections 3 and 4 is comparatively hard.So you have to ensure that you get 10 out of 10 in both section 1 and 2.It will help you to balance your mark. 
 

2. Give more time in practicing section 3 and section 4. When dealing with section 3 look at the speakers name carefully and point out what question is demanding from a particular speaker. 
 
 3. Get Cambridge IELTS Practice books. This books has been published in many versions try to practice at least 4 latest versions of this book. If you can get all the versions and practice all of them then it's very good for you. 4. Resources to follow : 
 ->Follow IELTS Liz YouTube Channel https://www.youtube.com/user/ieltsliz she has many good tutorials. or visit https://ieltsliz.com/ 
 -> Watch English TV series and try your best to follow the dialogues carefully. 
 -> Listen to BBC News at least once a day. 
 -> Listen to Podcasts. 
 These are some cool ways to improve your listening skill in a more efficient way.

Tips To Follow : 

 It is a good idea to study high quality writing styles in different formats by looking at newspapers or short articles in general-interest magazines on a variety of subjects. In magazines or newspapers, it can be useful to: 
 =>underline useful vocabulary items 
 =>underline and highlight grammar structures 
 =>underline linking devices between sentences and paragraphs 
 =>apply what you have learned to your own writing. 
 

Practice for both of the writing tasks. Looking at good quality examples can help. 

The Financial Times, for example, often provides tables and diagrams to illustrate texts on such things as the stock exchange which can serve as a useful model for Task 1 of the Academic Writing test. Short articles on topical subjects can be found in publications such as The Economist or, at a simpler level, free tabloids used by commuters going to and from work.

Tips To Follow : 

 1. Start taking in English inside home and outside as well. If it's hard to do get a friend with whom you can speak in English daily. 
 2. At home record your speaking with your phone and listen to it carefully find out the weak points and try to get over it. 
 3. When speaking make sure you're using different sentence structures such as Simple, Complex and Compound. 
 4. Try not to stammer when speaking it will reduce your score.
